3.name: return
3.description: Jumps back to after the last-executed call statement, and continues script execution from there.

4.name: call
4.description: Jumps to destination and continues script execution from there. The location of the calling script is remembered and can be returned to later.

5.name: jump
5.description: Jumps to destination and continues script execution from there.

6.name: jumpif
6.description: If the result of the last comparison matches condition (see Comparison operators), jumps to destination and continues script execution from there.

7.name: callif
7.description: If the result of the last comparison matches condition (see Comparison operators), calls destination.

8.name: jumpstd
8.description: Jumps to the standard function at index function.

9.name: callstd
9.description: Calls the standard function at index function.

10.name: jumpstdif
10.description: If the result of the last comparison matches condition (see Comparison operators), jumps to the standard function at index function.

11.name: callstdif
11.description: If the result of the last comparison matches condition (see Comparison operators), calls the standard function at index function.

12.name: jumpram
12.description: Executes a script stored in a default RAM location.

13.name: die
13.description: Terminates script execution and "resets the script RAM".

14.name: setbyte
14.description: Pads the specified value to a dword, and then writes that dword to a predefined address (0x0203AAA8).

15.name: loadptr
15.description: Sets the specified script bank to value.

16.name: setbufferbyte
16.description: Sets the specified script bank to value.

17.name: writebytetooffset
17.description: Sets the byte at offset to value.

18.name: loadbytefrompointer
18.description: Copies the byte value at source into the specified script bank.

19.name: setptrbyte
19.description: Not sure. Judging from XSE's description I think it takes the least-significant byte in bank source and writes it to destination.

20.name: copybuffers
20.description: Copies the contents of bank source into bank destination.

21.name: copybyte
21.description: Copies the byte at source to destination, replacing whatever byte was previously there.

22.name: setvar
22.description: Changes the value of destination to value.

23.name: addvar
23.description: Changes the value of destination by adding value to it. Overflow is not prevented (0xFFFF + 1 = 0x0000).

24.name: subvar
24.description: Changes the value of destination by subtracting value to it. Overflow is not prevented (0x0000 - 1 = 0xFFFF).

25.name: copyvar
25.description: Copies the value of source into destination.

26.name: setorcopyvar
26.description: If source is not a variable, then this function acts like setvar. Otherwise, it acts like copyvar.

27.name: comparebuffers
27.description: Compares the values of script banks a and b, after forcing the values to bytes.

28.name: comparebuffertobyte
28.description: Compares the least-significant byte of the value of script bank a to a fixed byte value (b).

29.name: comparebuffertoptrbyte
29.description: Compares the least-significant byte of the value of script bank a to the byte located at offset b.

30.name: compareptrbytetobuffer
30.description: Compares the byte located at offset a to the least-significant byte of the value of script bank b.

31.name: compareptrbytetobyte
31.description: Compares the byte located at offset a to a fixed byte value (b).

32.name: compareptrbytes
32.description: Compares the byte located at offset a to the byte located at offset b.

33.name: compare
33.description: Compares the value of `var` to a fixed word value (b).

34.name: comparevars
34.description: Compares the value of `var` to the value of `var2`.

35.name: callasm
35.description: Calls the ASM routine stored at code. Script execution is blocked until the ASM returns (bx lr, mov pc, lr, etc.). Remember to add 1 to the offset when calling THUMB code.

36.name: jumpasm
36.description: Replaces a pointer in the script engine RAM with asm_pointer.

37.name: special
37.description: Calls a special function; that is, a piece of ASM code designed for use by scripts and listed in a table of pointers.

38.name: specialval
38.description: Calls a special function. That function's output (if any) will be written to the variable you specify.

39.name: waitstate
39.description: Blocks script execution until a command or ASM code manually unblocks it. Generally used with specific commands and specials. If this command runs, and a subsequent command or piece of ASM does not unblock state, the script will remain blocked indefinitely (essentially a hang).

40.name: pause
40.description: Blocks script execution for time (frames? milliseconds?).

44.name: compareflags
44.description: In FireRed, this command is a nop.

45.name: checkdailyflags
45.description: In FireRed, this command is a nop.

46.name: resetvars
46.description: Resets the values of variables 0x8000, 0x8001, and 0x8002. Related to RTC in RSE?

47.name: playsfx
47.description: Plays the specified (sound_number) sound. Only one sound may play at a time, with newer ones interrupting older ones.

48.name: checksound
48.description: Blocks script execution until the currently-playing sound (triggered by sound) finishes playing.

50.name: waitfanfare
50.description: Blocks script execution until all currently-playing fanfares finish.

51.name: playmusic
51.description: Plays the specified (song_number) song. The byte is apparently supposed to be 0x00.

53.name: fadedefault
53.description: Crossfades the currently-playing song into the map's default song.

54.name: fademusic
54.description: Crossfades the currently-playng song into the specified (song_number) song.

56.name: fadein
56.description: Fades the currently-playing song back in.

57.name: warp
57.description: Sends the player to Warp warp on Map bank.map. If the specified warp is 0xFF, then the player will instead be sent to (X, Y) on the map.

58.name: warpmuted
58.description: Clone of warp that does not play a sound effect.

59.name: warpwalk
59.description: Clone of warp that uses "a walking effect".

60.name: warphole
60.description: Warps the player to another map using a hole animation.

61.name: warpteleport
61.description: Clone of warp that uses a teleport effect. It is apparently only used in R/S/E.[source]

62.name: warp3
62.description: Clone of warp. Used by an (unused?) Safari Zone script to return the player to the gatehouse and end the Safari Game.

63.name: warpplace
63.description: Sets a default warp place. If a warp tries to send the player to Warp 127 on Map 127.127, they will instead be sent here. Useful when a map has warps that need to go to script-controlled locations (i.e. elevators).

64.name: warpplace2
64.description: Clone of warp3, except that this writes data to different offsets...

65.name: warp5
65.description: Clone of warp3, except that this writes data to different offsets...

66.name: getplayerxy
66.description: Retrieves the player's zero-indexed X- and Y-coordinates in the map, and stores them in the specified variables.

67.name: countpokemon
67.description: Retrieves the number of Pokemon in the player's party, and stores that number in variable 0x800D (LASTRESULT).

68.name: additem
68.description: Attempts to add quantity of item index to the player's Bag. If the player has enough room, the item will be added and variable 0x800D (LASTRESULT) will be set to 0x0001; otherwise, LASTRESULT is set to 0x0000.

69.name: removeitem
69.description: Removes quantity of item index from the player's Bag.

70.name: checkitemspace
70.description: Checks if the player has enough space in their Bag to hold quantity more of item index. Sets variable 0x800D (LASTRESULT) to 0x0001 if there is room, or 0x0000 is there is no room.

71.name: checkitem
71.description: Checks if the player has quantity or more of item index in their Bag. Sets variable 0x800D (LASTRESULT) to 0x0001 if the player has enough of the item, or 0x0000 if they have fewer than quantity of the item.

72.name: checkitemtype
72.description: Checks which Bag pocket the specified (index) item belongs in, and writes the value to variable 0x800D (LASTRESULT). This script is used to show the name of the proper Bag pocket when the player receives an item via callstd (simplified to giveitem in XSE).

73.name: addpcitem
73.description: Adds a quantity amount of item index to the player's PC. Both arguments can be variables.

74.name: checkpcitem
74.description: Checks for quantity amount of item index in the player's PC. Both arguments can be variables.

75.name: adddecor
75.description: In FireRed, this command is a nop. (The argument is read, but not used for anything.)

76.name: removedecor
76.description: In FireRed, this command is a nop. (The argument is read, but not used for anything.)

77.name: testdecor
77.description: In FireRed, this command is a nop. (The argument is read, but not used for anything.)

78.name: checkdecor
78.description: In FireRed, this command is a nop. (The argument is read, but not used for anything.)

79.name: move
79.description: Applies the movement data at movements to the specified (index) Person event. Also closes any standard message boxes that are still open.

80.name: movecoords
80.description:
Apparent clone of applymovement. Oddly, it doesn't seem to work at all if applied to any Person other than the player (0xFF), and the X and Y arguments don't seem to do anything.
This command in fact uses variables to access the Person event ID. So, for example, if you setvar 0x8000 to 0x3, and then use applymovementpos 0x8000 @move1, Person event 3 will have the movements at @move1 applied to them. Thank you Shiny Quagsire for bringing this to my attention.

81.name: waitmove
81.description: Blocks script execution until the movements being applied to the specified (index) Person event finish. If the specified Person event is 0x0000, then the command will block script execution until all Person events affected by applymovement finish their movements. If the specified Person event is not currently being manipulated with applymovement, then this command does nothing.

82.name: waitmovexy
82.description: Apparent clone of waitmovement. Oddly, it doesn't seem to work at all if applied to any Person other than the player (0xFF), and the X and Y arguments don't seem to do anything.

83.name: disappear
83.description: Attempts to hide the specified (local_ID, a local ID) Person event on the current map, by setting its visibility flag if it has a valid one. If the Person does not have a valid visibility flag, this command does nothing.

84.name: disappearxy
84.description: Clone of hidesprite that also moves the Person? Test it!

90.name: faceplayer
90.description: If the script was called by a Person event, then that Person will turn to face toward the tile that the player is stepping off of.

92.name: trainerbattle
92.description: If the Trainer flag for Trainer index is not set, this command does absolutely nothing.

93.name: reptrainerbattle
93.description: Starts a trainer battle using the battle information stored in RAM (usually by trainerbattle, which actually calls this command behind-the-scenes), and blocks script execution until the battle finishes.

96.name: checktrainerflag
96.description: Compares Flag (trainer + 0x500) to 1. (If the flag is set, then the trainer has been defeated by the player.)

97.name: cleartrainerflag
97.description: Sets Flag (trainer + 0x500). (I didn't make a mistake. The command names actually are backwards.)

98.name: settrainerflag
98.description: Clears Flag (trainer + 0x500). (I didn't make a mistake. The command names actually are backwards.)

102.name: waittext
102.description: If a standard message box (or its text) is being drawn on-screen, this command blocks script execution until the box and its text have been fully drawn.

103.name: message
103.description: Starts displaying a standard message box containing the specified text. If text is a pointer, then the string at that offset will be loaded and used. If text is script bank 0, then the value of script bank 0 will be treated as a pointer to the text. (You can use loadpointer to place a string pointer in a script bank.)

104.name: closebutton
104.description: Holds the current message box open until the player presses a key. The message box is then closed.

105.name: lockall
105.description: Ceases movement for all OWs on-screen.

106.name: lock
106.description: If the script was called by a Person event, then that Person's movement will cease.

107.name: releaseall
107.description: Resumes normal movement for all OWs on-screen, and closes any standard message boxes that are still open.

108.name: release
108.description: If the script was called by a Person event, then that Person's movement will resume. This command also closes any standard message boxes that are still open.

109.name: waitbutton
109.description: Blocks script execution until the player presses any key.

110.name: yesnobox
110.description: Displays a YES/NO multichoice box at the specified coordinates, and blocks script execution until the user makes a selection. Their selection is stored in variable 0x800D (LASTRESULT); 0x0000 for "NO" or if the user pressed B, and 0x0001 for "YES".

111.name: multichoice
111.description: Displays a multichoice box from which the user can choose a selection, and blocks script execution until a selection is made. Lists of options are predefined and the one to be used is specified with list. If B is set to a non-zero value, then the user will not be allowed to back out of the multichoice with the B button.

112.name: multichoicedef
112.description: Displays a multichoice box from which the user can choose a selection, and blocks script execution until a selection is made. Lists of options are predefined and the one to be used is specified with list. The default argument determines the initial position of the cursor when the box is first opened; it is zero-indexed, and if it is too large, it is treated as 0x00. If B is set to a non-zero value, then the user will not be allowed to back out of the multichoice with the B button.

113.name: multichoicerow
113.description: Displays a multichoice box from which the user can choose a selection, and blocks script execution until a selection is made. Lists of options are predefined and the one to be used is specified with list. The per_row argument determines how many list items will be shown on a single row of the box.

117.name: showpokepic
117.description: Displays a box containing the front sprite for the specified (species) Pokemon species.

118.name: hidepokepic
118.description: Hides all boxes displayed with showpokepic.

119.name: showcontestwinner
119.description: In FireRed, this command is a nop. (The argument is discarded.)

120.name: braillemsg
120.description: Displays the string at pointer as braille text in a standard message box. The string must be formatted to use braille characters.

121.name: givepokemon
121.description: Gives the player one of the specified (species) Pokemon at level level holding item. The unknown arguments should all be zeroes.

124.name: checkattack
124.description: Checks if at least one Pokemon in the player's party knows the specified (index) attack. If so, variable 0x800D (LASTRESULT) is set to the (zero-indexed) slot number of the Pokemon that knows the move. If not, LASTRESULT is set to 0x0006.

125.name: bufferpoke
125.description: Writes the name of the Pokemon at index species to the specified buffer.

126.name: bufferfirstpoke
126.description: Writes the name of the first Pokemon in the player's party to the specified buffer.

127.name: bufferpartypoke
127.description: Writes the name of the Pokemon in slot slot (zero-indexed) of the player's party to the specified buffer. If an empty or invalid slot is specified, ten spaces ("") are written to the buffer.

128.name: bufferitem
128.description: Writes the name of the item at index item to the specified buffer. If the specified index is larger than the number of items in the game (0x176), the name of item 0 ("????????") is buffered instead.

129.name: bufferdecor
129.description: In FireRed, this command is a nop. (The first argument is discarded immediately. The second argument is read, but not used for anything.)

130.name: bufferattack
130.description: Writes the name of the attack at index attack to the specified buffer.

131.name: buffernum
131.description: Converts the value of input to a decimal string, and writes that string to the specified buffer.

132.name: bufferstd
132.description: Writes the standard string identified by index to the specified buffer. Specifying an invalid standard string (e.x. 0x2B) can and usually will cause data corruption (I've observed destruction of the stored player name and crashes when entering/exiting certain menu screens).

133.name: buffertext
133.description: Copies the string at offset to the specified buffer.

134.name: pokemart
134.description: Opens the Pokemart system, offering the specified products for sale.

138.name: event_8a
138.description: In FireRed, this command is a nop.

139.name: choosecontestpkmn
139.description: In FireRed, this command sets the byte at 0x03000EA8 to 0x01. I do not know what that means.

140.name: startcontest
140.description: In FireRed, this command is a nop.

141.name: showcontestresults
141.description: In FireRed, this command is a nop.

142.name: contestlinktransfer
142.description: In FireRed, this command is a nop.

143.name: random
143.description: Stores a random integer between 0 and limit in variable 0x800D (LASTRESULT).

144.name: givemoney
144.description: If check is 0x00, this command adds value to the player's money.

145.name: paymoney
145.description: If check is 0x00, this command subtracts value from the player's money.

146.name: checkmoney
146.description: If check is 0x00, this command will check if the player has value or more money; script variable 0x800D (LASTRESULT) is set to 0x0001 if the player has enough money, or 0x0000 if the do not.

147.name: showmoney
147.description: Spawns a secondary box showing how much money the player has.

148.name: hidemoney
148.description: Hides the secondary box spawned by showmoney.

149.name: updatemoney
149.description: Updates the secondary box spawned by showmoney. (What does it do with its arguments?)

150.name: event_96
150.description: In FireRed, this command is a nop.

151.name: fadescreen
151.description: Fades the screen to black or back, using the specified effect. Effect 0x00 fades in, and effect 0x01 fades out. I don't know if other effects exist.

156.name: doanimation
156.description: Executes the specified field move animation.

157.name: setanimation
157.description: Tells the game which party Pokemon to use for the next field move animation.

158.name: checkanimation
158.description: Blocks script execution until all playing field move animations complete.

159.name: sethealplace
159.description: Sets which healing place the player will return to if all of the Pokemon in their party faint. A list of available healing places can be found on PokeCommunity.

160.name: checkgender
160.description: Checks the player's gender. If male, then 0x0000 is stored in variable 0x800D (LASTRESULT). If female, then 0x0001 is stored in LASTRESULT.

161.name: pokecry
161.description: Plays the specified (species) Pokemon's cry. You can use waitcry to block script execution until the sound finishes.

162.name: setmaptile
162.description: Changes the tile at (X, Y) on the current map.

163.name: resetweather
163.description: Queues a weather change to the default weather for the map.

164.name: setweather
164.description: Queues a weather change to type weather.

165.name: doweather
165.description: Executes the weather change queued with resetweather or setweather. The current weather will smoothly fade into the queued weather.

166.name: tileeffect
166.description: This command manages cases in which maps have tiles that change state when stepped on (specifically, cracked/breakable floors).

172.name: setdooropened
172.description: Queues the opening of the door tile at (X, Y) with an animation.

173.name: setdoorclosed
173.description: Queues the closing of the door tile at (X, Y) with an animation.

174.name: doorchange
174.description: Executes the state changes queued with setdooropened, setdoorclosed, setdooropened2, and setdoorclosed2.

175.name: setdooropened2
175.description: Queues the opening of the door tile at (X, Y) without an animation.

176.name: setdoorclosed2
176.description: Queues the closing of the door tile at (X, Y) without an animation.

177.name: event_b1
177.description: In FireRed, this command is a nop.

178.name: event_b2
178.description: In FireRed, this command is a nop.

182.name: setwildbattle
182.description: Prepares to start a wild battle against a species at Level level holding item. Running this command will not affect normal wild battles. You start the prepared battle with dowildbattle.

183.name: dowildbattle
183.description: Starts a wild battle against the Pokemon generated by setwildbattle. Blocks script execution until the battle finishes.

192.name: showcoins
192.description: Spawns a secondary box showing how many Coins the player has.

193.name: hidecoins
193.description: Hides the secondary box spawned by showcoins. It doesn't appear to use its arguments, but they are still required.

194.name: updatecoins
194.description: Updates the secondary box spawned by showcoins. (What does it do with its arguments?)

195.name: inccounter
195.description: Increases the value of the specified hidden variable by 1. The hidden variable's value will not be allowed to exceed 0x00FFFFFF.

196.name: warp6
196.description: Clone of warp... Except that it doesn't appear to have any effect when used in some of FireRed's default level scripts. (If it did, Berry Forest would be impossible to enter...)

197.name: waitpokecry
197.description: Blocks script execution until cry finishes.

198.name: bufferboxname
198.description: Writes the name of the specified (box) PC box to the specified buffer.

199.name: textcolor
199.description: Sets the color of the text in standard message boxes. 0x00 produces blue (male) text, 0x01 produces red (female) text, 0xFF resets the color to the default for the current OW's gender, and all other values produce black text.

200.name: loadhelp
200.description: The exact purpose of this command is unknown, but it is related to the blue help-text box that appears on the bottom of the screen when the Main Menu is opened.

201.name: unloadhelp
201.description: The exact purpose of this command is unknown, but it is related to the blue help-text box that appears on the bottom of the screen when the Main Menu is opened.

202.name: signmsg
202.description: After using this command, all standard message boxes will use the signpost frame.

203.name: normalmsg
203.description: Ends the effects of signmsg, returning message box frames to normal.

204.name: comparehiddenvar
204.description: Compares the value of a hidden variable to a dword.

205.name: setobedience
205.description: Makes the Pokemon in the specified slot of the player's party obedient. It will not randomly disobey orders in battle.

206.name: checkobedience
206.description: Checks if the Pokemon in the specified slot of the player's party is obedient. If the Pokemon is disobedient, 0x0001 is written to script variable 0x800D (LASTRESULT). If the Pokemon is obedient (or if the specified slot is empty or invalid), 0x0000 is written.

207.name: execram
207.description: Depending on factors I haven't managed to understand yet, this command may cause script execution to jump to the offset specified by the pointer at 0x020370A4.

208.name: setworldflag
208.description: Sets worldmapflag to 1. This allows the player to Fly to the corresponding map, if that map has a flightspot.

209.name: warpteleport2
209.description: Clone of warpteleport? It is apparently only used in FR/LG, and only with specials.[source]

210.name: setcatchlocale
210.description: Changes the location where the player caught the Pokemon in the specified slot of their party. A list of valid catch locations can be found on PokeCommunity.

213.name: event_d5
213.description: In FireRed, this command is a nop.

226.name: storeitems
226.description: Writes the name of the specified (item) item to the specified buffer. If the specified item is a Berry (0x85 - 0xAE) or Poke Ball (0x4) and if the quantity is 2 or more, the buffered string will be pluralized ("IES" or "S" appended). If the specified item is the Enigma Berry, I have no idea what this command does (but testing showed no pluralization). If the specified index is larger than the number of items in the game (0x176), the name of item 0 ("????????") is buffered instead.
